questions.question_text: An analysis of a threat actor, which has been active for several years, reveals the threat actor has high levels of funding, motivation, and sophistication. Which of the following types of threat actors does this BEST describe?

discussion.content:
Answer is correct.
NATION STATE ACTORS/ADVANCED PERSISTENT THREATS (APTs)
Most nation states have developed cybersecurity expertise and will use cyber weapons to achieve both military and commercial goals. The security company Mandiant's APT1 report into Chinese cyber espionage units (https://fireeye.com/content/dam/fireeye-www/services/pdfs/mandiant-apt1-report.pdf) was hugely influential in shaping the language and understanding of modern cyber-attack lifecycles. The term Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) was coined to understand the behavior underpinning modern types of cyber adversaries. Rather than think in terms of systems being infected with a virus or rootkit, an APT refers to the ongoing ability of an adversary to compromise network security (to obtain and maintain access) using a variety of tools and techniques.

Reference: COM501B
Security+ Review Guide Fourth Edition.
Also the fact that the threat actor has been active for "several years" suggests persistent.

comments.content: "high levels of funding, motivation, and sophistication" = APT
Think about if "high levels of funding, motivation, and sophistication" is a better description of a national cyber intelligence agency or of organized credit card criminals.

choices.A: A host was identified as a web server that is hosting multiple domains
choices.B: A host was scanned, and web-based vulnerabilities were found
choices.D: A web shell was planted in company.com's content management system
choices.C: A connection was established to a domain, and several redirect connections were identified

discussion.content: This is a security exam so you have to think in terms of security and having multiple domains using port 80 is not secure and is considered a vulnerability. Answer is B.
I also think that the answer should be A

comments.content: I think it's B because the server is using port 80 (http) which is not secure.

discussion.content: Answer has to be A, no?

ECB: encrypt each block with the same key (simplest)
CBC: combines each block with the previous block + IV
CTM: CBC + Counter
GCM: CTM + hash for integrity

The answer is correct.
Cipher block chaining (CBC) is a mode of operation for a block cipher (one in which a sequence of bits are encrypted as a single unit or block with a cipher key applied to the entire block). Cipher block chaining uses what is known as an initialization vector (IV) of a certain length.

The cipher block chaining (CBC) mode produces much stronger
encryption by XORing the previous block to the block being encrypted. The
very first block introduces an initialization vector (IV) into the process.
This ensures that every block of plaintext input into the process produces a
uniquely different piece of ciphertext. So even when the same block of
plaintext is input repeatedly, the resultant ciphertext will not be identical to
any previous outputs.

discussion.content: poor A user, a logic bomb that deletes everything on the date of his birthday..

questions.question_text: An organization requires three separate factors for authentication to sensitive systems. Which of the following would BEST satisfy the requirement?

choices.D: Password, one-time password sent to a smartphone, and text message sent to a smartphone
choices.A: Fingerprint, PIN, and mother's maiden name
choices.B: One-time password sent to a smartphone, thumbprint, and home street address

discussion.content: The answer is B; -Something you have: One-time password sent to a smartphone -Something you are: Thumbprint -Something you know: Home street address

Selected Answer: B
* Password, PIN, mother's maiden name, and a home st add are something you know 
* Fingerprints and voice recognition are something you are
* One-time passwords and text messages are something you have

You need one from each category to establish MFA (multifactor authentication).
Option B is the correct answer!
